body:
Problem:
Can't show 'statusline' in floating windows.

Solution:
Use window-local 'statusline' ~~and 'laststatus'~~ to control floating
window statusline visibility.



Fix #16753

comment_data.body: Currently it is not controlled by style; it only depends on the floating window local statusline option. Since the default value is empty, floating statuslines will not appear. It is rendered only when this value is non-empty and laststatus is set to 1 or 2. Adding style control would require updating many existing float_spec tests.

That is irrelevant. `style='minimal'` is a way for users to say "use the minimal style".

> Adding style control would require updating many existing float_spec tests.

Why? The `before_each` in those tests can simply `:setlocal` to avoid big changes.

comment_regular_data.body:
> When set to true and laststatus is not 0, the statusline will be rendered in floating windows

wouldn't it make sense to *not* render the statusline in floating windows when `laststatus == 3` (global statusline)?

That was also how I implemented it at the beginning, it only rendered when laststatus was 2. But floating windows aren’t organized in the  tree structure as normal windows, so they behave differently. Maybe rendering it when laststatus is 3 could also make sense for some users?

> That was also how I implemented it at the beginning, it only rendered when laststatus was 2. But floating windows aren’t organized in the tree structure as normal windows, so they behave differently. Maybe rendering it when laststatus is 3 could also make sense for some users?

Does this PR change the behavior of `laststatus=3` so the global statusline on the bottom only reflects windows in the tree structure? (as opposed to how it does currently, where it always reflects the active window, even if it's floating) If so, that's great, but if not, wouldn't that just make the same statusline appear twice?
emm when laststatus is set to 3, the statusline of floating windows does not appear in the latest commit.  I think floating windows should also follow the global semantics of laststatus=3 🤔
Great, just double checking.
Rebase 🙈

Just remembered a question that [I asked in the issue](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/16753#issuecomment-1256977133):  'statusline' is already window-local. Why do we need a new WinConfig field?

Note that WinConfig has a `style="minimal"` field, which is the default, and that can also be used to unset 'statusline' by default. And we already do that for 'statuscolumn'...

`laststatus` is a global option, and the visibility of the statusline is controlled by this option. I think you may be mixing up `:help statusline`. this option is global and local-window and defines the statusline expression (the stl format string); it does not control whether the statusline is shown.

> which is the default, and that can also be used to unset 'statusline' by default. And we already do that for 'statuscolumn'...

ok

But who cares about 'laststatus'? Currently, floating windows can show 'statuscolumn' but not 'statusline'. And that isn't because of 'laststatus', which is just a detail.

The main purpose of https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/16753 and this PR is to show statusline in a floatwin.

> using “style” to control the statusline doesn't seem correct. so what would happen if no style field is set? 

If `style="minimal"` is not set then the plugin author has decided they don't want "minimal" style. And they can explicitly `:setlocal statusline=` (empty) in the floatwin if they want.

> would we just render a statusline unconditionally?

It is conditional on whether the window-local 'statusline' option is set, same as all windows. Same as 'statuscolumn' ...

I understand what you mean.  just a bit concerned that floating windows not using style=minimal might end up showing a statusline after this PR, which could introduce some visual noise... But fine, let’s go ahead with it.

> :setlocal statusline= (empty) in the floatwin if they want.

notice we set stl expr in options.lua so this won't work..

> notice we set stl expr in options.lua so this won't work..

That is the default, but `:setlocal` will override it for the floatwin. 

> floating windows not using style=minimal might end up showing a statusline after this PR, which could introduce some visual noise

Yes, plugin authors will need to adapt. In the long run, adding extra, redundant options feels worse for all parties.

> That is the default, but :setlocal will override it for the floatwin.

Sry does this mean that :setlocal stl= will also clear the statusline of floating windows 🤔
Related #18660
Oh, I see. Thanks.

> > That is the default, but :setlocal will override it for the floatwin.
> 
> Sry does this mean that :setlocal stl= will also clear the statusline of floating windows 🤔

Yes, 

- `:setlocal statusline=` will disable the statusline for the specific floating window where `:setlocal` was executed. Like any other window-local option. Like how `:setlocal statuscolumn=` already works.
- this should be the default for `style="minimal"`

It's true that `:setlocal statusline=` doesn't work like that for non-floating windows but I don't think that matters?

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/18660 is related but not a blocker. However, it probably makes sense to work on that as a followup.

'statusline' is not a window-local option. It's a "global or local to window" option. The local value is already empty by default.

However, #18773 already added a special case for 'winbar', so adding the same special case for 'statusline' does make sense.

Yes. So I think the problem can be simplified here. We only need to handle the case where a floating window explicitly sets `setlocal stl`. If it’s non-empty, show the statusline; if it’s empty, clear the statusline. And we still need to respect laststatus. This way, we don’t rely on style,  If use style to control it, then many of the float_spec tests would have to be changed.

now display is controlled through the floating window local stl option and laststatus.

![test4](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/9fa5ce8c-0f01-4c97-b82c-2683a6d503fa)

Nice, this looks simpler and we're almost there.

> And we still need to respect laststatus

Why does 'laststatus' matter for floating windows? The common case is that floatwins won't show statusline. But the ones that DO want to show a custom statusline should not have to care about 'laststatus'.

However, for now, whatever is simpler to implement is better.

> This way, we don’t rely on style, If use style to control it, then many of the float_spec tests would have to be changed.

Tests can simply `:setlocal` or whatever, then the screentest doesn't need to be updated.

If a plugin specifies `style='minimal'`, then `nvim_open_win` should perform `:setlocal nostatusline`. It shouldn't be complicated.

> > And we still need to respect laststatus
> 
> Why does 'laststatus' matter for floating windows? The common case is that floatwins won't show statusline. But the ones that DO want to show a custom statusline should not have to care about 'laststatus'.

Doesn't it matter because it would cause the statusline to be duplicated twice, once in the floating window and once in global statusline? Unless this PR also changes the global statusline to not reflect the floating window in this case (and reflect the last used non-floating window or something).

> Doesn't it matter because it would cause the statusline to be duplicated twice, once in the floating window and once in global statusline?

IIUC, floatwins by default will not show a statusline. So if a floatwin *is* showing a statusline, then presumably a plugin has a reason to be showing a (customized, local) statusline. That is a different use-case than 'laststatus'. It's not a normal window where the statusline is showing just for the heck of it.
Removed laststatus control over the statusline of floating window

Heads-up: this broke telescope, and likely other plugins that rely on floating windows for their UI, when using a statusline plugin (lualine, in my case). Also seems to have some performance impact (but not going to investigate that further for now).

@shadmansaleh

> this broke telescope, and likely other plugins that rely on floating windows for their UI, when using a statusline plugin

how? the local statusline is not shown by default

> Also seems to have some performance impact

@glepnir is the window being redrawn/reconfigured more often than necessary?

> how? the local statusline is not shown by default Sorry, a screenshot would have been helpful. Note how the last row of the two floating windows (with the border) is replaced by a black line (which also overlaps the first row of the next window). My guess is that some of the new code messes up the height calculation and hence the placement in some situations. (As I wrote, this doesn't happen with the default statusline.)
It seems that lualine sets both the global and window local statusline, even though they are the same value.

I wonder if lualine is explicitly setting the local statusline (which would be a bug in lualine) or if the global value of statusline is being inherited without correct handling (which would be a bug in this PR). In a few hours when I have access to my computer again, I'll check.

I think we do set both global and local statusline I'll have to check though. IIRC global is used as fallback and local stl value is used primarily for rendering to provide filetyoe specific statuslines through extensions. I'll have to check if that's the case now. What would be the expected behavior from neovim after this pr?

On lualines side we already had statuslines for floating windows even before this pr. The statuslines were basically rendered on global status or on statusline of last active window IIRC. Personally I feel like rendering on global status is better solution then putting one on each float. Floats already had winbar even before this right? So if anything specific needed to be shown for float it could've already been done on winbar.

'statusline' for floating windows is empty by default, so creating a floating window won’t render a statusline. It has no impact. Only if a plugin sets a local stl after the every window is created will it cause the statusline to be drawn.

> Floats already had winbar even before this right?

Yes, as do splits. But they are in different places :)

There are a few bugs here when the current window at moment of opening float already has a local-statusline set. **With 'laststatus=2'** 1. Even though the statusline option on flaot is never set it's displaying the global-statusline option. It gets fixed if I explicitly set stl= after creating float. But it doesn't make sense why anyone creating a float will need to explicitly do that when the statusline-opt is already empty. **With laststatus=3** 2. When focus is on flaoting window the statusline on lastwindow no longer updates and if you trigger a redraw (``) the statusline completely disapears. Also, with laststatus=3 with local statusline set on the split when opening float it creates an extra line on float for statusline, but doesn't even display anything. 3. What the behavior for laststatus=3 before this pr was no matter where the focus currently is (split or float) the statusline gets drawn in last line of neovim. The statusline get's drawn in context of the current focus window. Means if even if I was in a split or on a float not connected to last line of neovim the statusline still draws the winlocal stl option for the window where focus is. So in this case for laststatus=3 statusline for flaoting windows was already there. I believe floats should maintain that behavior because with laststatus=3 splits also does the same. If I remember currectly with laststatus=3 entire point was to have one single statusline always at the same spot. Floating windows not respecting that after this pr breaks that. Tbh floating window status should fully comply with laststatus. Some windows follwoing a global option and some not isn't consistent. **test-code** ```lua local buf = vim.api.nvim_create_buf(false, true) vim.opt.laststatus = 2 vim.api.nvim_set_option_value('statusline', 'global', {}) local curwin = vim.api.nvim_get_current_win() vim.api.nvim_set_option_value('statusline', 'split-local', {win=curwin}) local opts = { relative = "editor", row = 10, col = 30, width = 50, height = 1, border = 'single' } local win = vim.api.nvim_open_win(buf, true, opts) -- vim.api.nvim_set_option_value('statusline', '', {win=win}) ``` I think the primary issue is that winopts is getting inherited wrongly somewhere. and `laststatus` not being handled.

laststatus does not affect the statusline of floating windows, so its value is irrelevant.  your report should be fixed in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/36716. You can give it a try, and if there are any problems, discuss in there, this place is no longer suitable for that discussion. thanks
